items.title: ImportError: cannot import name 'Reporter'
items.body:
**coverage and coveralls work well in local environment but not on Travis CI.**

installed python packages in virtualenv in local environment are
```
(django) ubuntu@ip-172-31-12-72:~/django$ pip list
Package             Version
------------------- ----------
asgiref             3.2.3
certifi             2019.11.28
chardet             3.0.4
coverage            5.0.2
coveralls           1.10.0
Django              3.0.2
djangorestframework 3.11.0
docopt              0.6.2
entrypoints         0.3
flake8              3.7.9
idna                2.8
mccabe              0.6.1
pip                 19.3.1
pycodestyle         2.5.0
pyflakes            2.1.1
python-coveralls    2.9.3
pytz                2019.3
PyYAML              5.2
requests            2.22.0
setuptools          44.0.0
six                 1.13.0
sqlparse            0.3.0
urllib3             1.25.7
wheel               0.33.6
```

and I tested coverage and coverage worked well

```
(django) ubuntu@ip-172-31-12-72:~/django$ coverage run --source=pollsapi/polls pollsapi/manage.py test pollsapi
Creating test database for alias 'default'...
System check identified no issues (0 silenced).
...
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 3 tests in 0.655s

OK
Destroying test database for alias 'default'...
(django) ubuntu@ip-172-31-12-72:~/django$ coverage report
Name                                        Stmts   Miss  Cover
---------------------------------------------------------------
pollsapi/polls/__init__.py                      0      0   100%
pollsapi/polls/admin.py                         4      0   100%
pollsapi/polls/apiviews.py                     56     23    59%
pollsapi/polls/apps.py                          3      3     0%
pollsapi/polls/migrations/0001_initial.py       7      0   100%
pollsapi/polls/migrations/__init__.py           0      0   100%
pollsapi/polls/models.py                       19      2    89%
pollsapi/polls/serializers.py                  29      5    83%
pollsapi/polls/tests.py                        33      0   100%
pollsapi/polls/urls.py                          8      0   100%
pollsapi/polls/views.py                        12     12     0%
---------------------------------------------------------------
TOTAL                                         171     45    74%
```

and it reported to coveralls.io successfully

```
(django) ubuntu@ip-172-31-12-72:~/django$ coveralls
Submitting coverage to coveralls.io...
Coverage submitted!
Job ##6.1
https://coveralls.io/jobs/57700125
```

but the problem is that this doesn't work on Travis CI.

Here's .travis.yml (requirements.txt is created by `pip freeze > requirements.txt`)

```
(django) ubuntu@ip-172-31-12-72:~/django$ cat .travis.yml
language: python
dist: bionic
git:
  clone: true
  autocrlf: true
virtualenv:
  system_site_packages: true
install:
  - pip install -r requirements.txt
script:
  - flake8
  - python pollsapi/manage.py test pollsapi
  - coverage run --source=pollsapi/polls pollsapi/manage.py test pollsapi
after_success:
  - coveralls
#jobs:
#  include:
#    - stage: "Test"
#      name: "Unit Tests"
#      script: echo "Running unit tests..."
#      script: *******
#    - name: "Integration Tests"
#      script: echo "Running integration tests..."
#      script: ********
```

on Travis CI, I get this error every time I merge changes onto master branch

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33472400/72216790-f87c7b80-3568-11ea-904d-b524c48b211b.png)

items.title: Send '.coverage' docker output to coveralls from travis
items.body:
I've generated a coverage report from my flask [`app.py`](https://github.com/jeff1evesque/machine-learning/blob/00fce3b9b1587e13493d63398fa1a07770492414/app.py#L21-L25) as follows:

```python
        pytest.main([
            '--cov', '.',
            '--cov-report', 'xml:/var/machine-learning/coverage.xml',
            'test/live_server'
        ])
```

**Note:** the above syntax was predicated on my [installing](https://github.com/jeff1evesque/machine-learning/blob/bdf8cdcce1b8fcb9efd8c0fbffa599c124bd647f/default.dockerfile#L31) the `pytest-cov` package.

Since this report is generated from a docker container, spun up by travis ci, I needed to redirect the output to the above indicated `/var/machine-learning/coverage.xml`.  However, this file needed to be [copied](https://github.com/jeff1evesque/machine-learning/blob/f68c2acd5edaeb233097b6455aa2f4eaeca12f2b/.travis.yml#L118) from the docker container, to the ubuntu 14.04 host, running the docker unit testing environment:

```yaml
 - docker cp webserver-pytest:/var/machine-learning/coverage.xml coverage.xml
```

So, I proceeded to [injest](https://github.com/jeff1evesque/machine-learning/blob/f68c2acd5edaeb233097b6455aa2f4eaeca12f2b/.travis.yml#L129-L131) this `coverage.xml` into the `coveralls` command:

```yaml
## post build: the following commands are run after a successful, or failed build.
after_success:
  - coveralls --data_file=coverage.xml
```

**Note:** the generated `coverage.xml` can be [reviewed](https://travis-ci.org/jeff1evesque/machine-learning/builds/192214255#L4094-L6722) within the `.travis.yml` output.

This generated the following [traceback](https://travis-ci.org/jeff1evesque/machine-learning/builds/192214255#L6751-L6763) when travis ci ran:

>$ coveralls --data_file=coverage.xml
>
>Traceback (most recent call last):
>
>  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python2.7.12/bin/coveralls", line 11, in <module>
>
>    sys.exit(wear())
>
>  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python2.7.12/lib/python2.7/site-packages/coveralls/__init__.py", line 87, in wear
>
>    coverage.load()
>
>  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python2.7.12/lib/python2.7/site-packages/coverage/control.py", line 664, in load
>
>    self.data_files.read(self.data)
>
>  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python2.7.12/lib/python2.7/site-packages/coverage/data.py", line 636, in read
>
>    data.read_file(self.filename)
>
>  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python2.7.12/lib/python2.7/site-packages/coverage/data.py", line 295, in read_file
>
>    filename, exc.__class__.__name__, exc,
>
>coverage.misc.CoverageException: Couldn't read data from '/home/travis/build/jeff1evesque/machine-learning/coverage.xml': CoverageException: Doesn't seem to be a coverage.py data file

**Note:** the above problem is associated with an [existing issue](https://github.com/jeff1evesque/machine-learning/issues/2697), which has commits that can be reviewed.

items.title: Mercurial support broken
items.body: There is still one use of [`sh` left](https://github.com/z4r/python-coveralls/blob/d2283b98c8f1635d5100ed2b007adcea2fbf2630/coveralls/repository.py#L44) despite its removal of a dependency in PR ( https://github.com/z4r/python-coveralls/pull/53 ). It is also not imported in that module so will be undefined.

items.title: Support: COVERALLS_SERVICE_NAME env var
items.body:
I want to get rid of .coveralls.yml. It would be nice to have support reading this key:
COVERALLS_SERVICE_NAME

Use Case:
Private travis repo requires these 2 keys: COVERALLS_REPO_TOKEN and COVERALLS_SERVICE_NAME

items.title: python-coveralls 2.6.0 requires .coveragerc file
items.body:
If the user does not have a `.coveragerc` file in their repo, `coveralls` command fails with:

``` bash
$ coveralls
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python2.7.9/bin/coveralls", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(wear())
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python2.7.9/lib/python2.7/site-packages/coveralls/__init__.py", line 86, in wear
    coverage = coveralls(data_file=args.data_file, config_file=args.config_file)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python2.7.9/lib/python2.7/site-packages/coverage/control.py", line 140, in __init__
    "Couldn't read '%s' as a config file" % config_file
coverage.misc.CoverageException: Couldn't read '/home/travis/build/<TRAVISUSER>/<PATH>/.coveragerc' as a config file
```

Perhaps this is regression introduced by changes in the coverage 4.0 API?

items.title: Failed to install python-coveralls 2.5 in windows 7
items.body:
sh is apparently the successor to pbs but no longer supports Windows

In windows 7, running `pip install python-coveralls==2.5.0` I get the following error:

```
Using cached sh-1.11.tar.gz
Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 20, in <module>
  File "c:\users\saeed\appdata\local\temp\pip-build-n7zgsf\sh\setup.py", line 4, in <module>
    import sh
  File "sh.py", line 37, in <module>
    support." % __version__)
ImportError: sh 1.11 is currently only supported on linux and osx. please install pbs 0.110 (http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pbs) for windows support.
```

Would you mind adding windows support by allowing pbs as a replace of sh in windows OS.

items.title: No Longer Working: Cannot Import Name 'coverage'
items.body: I'm attempting to use this library with the latest release, but am having issues. It looks like some internal stuff is breaking via imports: This happens for every version of python on travis :(

items.title: coveralls problem with non-UTF-8 character from external library
items.body:
I am running my test coverage assessment through Django Nose, using the following option (@settings.py):

```
NOSE_ARGS = [
    '--verbosity=3',
    '--cover-package=services.accounts,services.common,'
    'services.communications,services.configuration,services.leop,'
    'services.network,services.scheduling,services.simulation'
]
```

As you can see, I am restricting the assessment of the coverage only to the packages that I develop by myself. The sequence of commands that I use in order to execute this assessment is the following:

```
coverarge erase
coverage run manage.py test
coveralls
```

When invoking "coveralls", it tries to run the coverage assessment also over the external libraries, so that I get the following exception when it tries to access to the source code for "datetime":

```
>>> filename = /home/rtubio/repositories/satnet/server/development_3k/.venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/dateutil/parser.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/rtubio/repositories/satnet/server/development_3k/.venv/bin/coveralls", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(wear())
  File "/home/rtubio/repositories/satnet/server/development_3k/.venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/coveralls/__init__.py", line 91, in wear
    source_files=coverage.coveralls(args.base_dir, ignore_errors=args.ignore_errors, merge_file=args.merge_file),
  File "/home/rtubio/repositories/satnet/server/development_3k/.venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/coveralls/control.py", line 9, in coveralls
    return reporter.report(base_dir, ignore_errors=ignore_errors, merge_file=merge_file)
  File "/home/rtubio/repositories/satnet/server/development_3k/.venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/coveralls/report.py", line 14, in report
    source = fp.readlines()
  File "/home/rtubio/repositories/satnet/server/development_3k/.venv/lib/python3.4/codecs.py", line 313, in decode
    (result, consumed) = self._buffer_decode(data, self.errors, final)
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xdf in position 1130: invalid continuation byte
```

The first line (>>> filename = 'XXXX') was manually added by my to "coveralls/report.py:12", since the original exception does not report the name of the file that provokes the exception to be thrown (following the recommendation from https://github.com/eddyxu/cpp-coveralls/issues/24). In that very same issue, they suggest the usage of '--exclude', an option that seems to be available for "cpp-coveralls" but not for "python-coveralls".

Therefore, the following questions arise:

1) Is the coverage tool ignoring the option for django-nose in which I specify the package over which to assess the coverage?
2) Is there anyway in which I can tell "coveralls" to ignore certain packages?

Thanks for the help in advance.

items.title: Report sent to coveralls includes library files
items.body:
Sorry if I'm missing something obvious with my set-up but I noticed that the coveralls report for my project includes library files.

See the Travis-CI output for my build goes as

```
$ nosetests --with-xcoverage
.......
Name    Stmts   Miss  Cover   Missing
-------------------------------------
titan      61      3    95%   58, 77, 87
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 7 tests in 0.807s
OK
```

But at coveralls I only have 27.61% coverage. The culprit is that files such as `/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.2.5/lib/python3.2/site-packages/nose/*py` (as well as other packages) have been included.

How do I uninclude library files?

items.title: ImportError when run with TravisCI
items.body:
This has worked in the past, but I just ran a build today and am now getting:
`ImportError: cannot import name coverage`

Here's the job that is now failing for me: https://travis-ci.org/cobbdb/jsinclude/jobs/36921871#L87
Here is how I'm calling coveralls in my tox file: https://github.com/cobbdb/jsinclude/blob/master/tox.ini#L39

Here is the relevant section from the console output:

```
45 passed in 1.02 seconds
py33-1.6-coverage runtests: commands[1] | coveralls
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".tox/py33-1.6-coverage/bin/coveralls", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(wear())
  File "/home/travis/build/cobbdb/jsinclude/.tox/py33-1.6-coverage/lib/python3.3/site-packages/coveralls/__init__.py", line 73, in wear
    from coveralls.control import coveralls
  File "/home/travis/build/cobbdb/jsinclude/.tox/py33-1.6-coverage/lib/python3.3/site-packages/coveralls/control.py", line 1, in <module>
    from coverage.control import coverage
ImportError: cannot import name coverage
```

items.title: sh requirement precludes installation on windows
items.body:
the [sh](https://github.com/amoffat/sh) module is listed as a requirement, and it still explicitly does not work on windows. You'll get an error message that looks like this:

```
Downloading/unpacking sh (from python-coveralls)
  Downloading sh-1.09.tar.gz
  Running setup.py (path:C:\Users\test\configobj\.tox\py26\build\sh\setup.py) egg_info for package sh
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 17, in <module>
      File "C:\Users\test\configobj\.tox\py26\build\sh\setup.py", line 4, in <module>
        import sh
      File "sh.py", line 34, in <module>
        support." % __version__)
    ImportError: sh 1.09 is currently only supported on linux and osx. please install pbs 0.110 (http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pbs) for windows support.
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<string>", line 17, in <module>

  File "C:\Users\test\configobj\.tox\py26\build\sh\setup.py", line 4, in <module>

    import sh

  File "sh.py", line 34, in <module>

    support." % __version__)

ImportError: sh 1.09 is currently only supported on linux and osx. please install pbs 0.110 (http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pbs) for windows support.
```

So, going forward, I'd expect either:
- being ok with python-coveralls working on OS X/linux only (since that's all of Travis and most of the other CI solutions out there) and failing fast in python-coveralls's setup.py
- refactoring the use of sh to use pbs (or stdlib subprocess) if it's not onerouse, because eh, why not?

Some background my [project](https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj) uses tox to run the tests locally, and travis just runs tox. This meant I had some windows developers run into this when I listed python-coveralls as a tox dependency.

I can refactor coveralls to be only installed in travis, but figured I'd pass it on. Thanks.

items.title: Support wheel packaging
items.body: It would be really nice if python-coveralls supported wheel packages. It's the future of python packaging, it's easy to provide and the best part is that it speeds up a lot the install process :) (very usefull for CI)

items.title: "coveralls" breaks Travis build
items.body:
It seems that in some builds the `coveralls` command fails to reach coveralls.io and exits with a status code of `1`. This breaks the build even if all the tests passed. I'd prefer more control over this, maybe by adding an option to silence `coveralls` and make it exit with `0` even if it fails to reach the server.

Example builds:
https://travis-ci.org/rubik/mando/jobs/14812821
https://travis-ci.org/rubik/mando/jobs/14817069

Note that this always happens in the Python 2.7 environment, while for the same build it succedes with Python 3.2, 3.3 and pypy.

items.title: argparse should only be a requirement for Python 2.6
items.body: Could you please remove `argparse` from `requirements.txt` and make it only get added in `setup.py` when `sys.version_info < (2, 7)`?  No one should be installing the `argparse` module themselves in 2.7+.

items.body:

$ coveralls
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "/Users/s2092651/lib/python2.7/site-packages/coveralls/repository.py", line 9, in gitrepo

    return RunningCommand(cmd, call_args, stdin, stdout, stderr)
  File "/Users/s2092651/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sh.py", line 291, in __init__

  File "/Users/s2092651/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sh.py", line 309, in _handle_exit_code

sh.ErrorReturnCode_128: 

  RAN: '/usr/local/bin/git --no-pager log -1 --pretty=format:%H%n%aN%n%ae%n%cN%n%ce%n%s'

items.title: Backward compatibility with Python 2.5
items.body:
Would be nice to have support for Python 2.5

Traceback: https://travis-ci.org/appliedsec/pygeoip/jobs/10399596

items.title: coveralls script always returns non-zero return code
items.body:
Running `coveralls` will always return a non-zero exit code which causes problems in some situations. For example, automated CI, specifically Codeship which will stop the build process of any commands return a non-zero exit code. 

The function that is called by the `coveralls` console-script should return a 0 exit code on success and a non-zero exit on of failure.

items.title: Skip missing files during coverage report
items.body:
Often times coverage reports contain missing files. This happens when tests create temporary files and import them (and then delete them), but also when using virtualenv (in which cases modules have fake or tampered file names).

Currently `coveralls` fails for such cases:

```
 Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/coveralls", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('python-coveralls==2.2.0', 'console_scripts', 'coveralls')() 
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/coveralls/__init__.py", line 84, in wear
    source_files=coverage.coveralls(args.base_dir),
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/coveralls/control.py", line 7, in coveralls
    return CoverallsReporter(self, self.config).report(base_dir)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/coveralls/report.py", line 9, in report
    with open(cu.filename) as fp:
  IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/tmp2sSAzd/dir_1/dir_2/test_2.py'
```

items.title: Doesn't work...
items.body:
https://travis-ci.org/moschlar/SAUCE/jobs/8632210#L4443

Don't know if it's maybe related to coveralls.io having some problems: lemurheavy/coveralls-public#81

items.title: Can I use an ENV var with CircleCI...
items.body:
...like you can with Ruby/Rails like this:

OVERALLS_REPO_TOKEN=asdfasdf bundle exec rspec spec

as described here:
https://coveralls.io/docs/ruby

but with Python, so something like:

OVERALLS_REPO_TOKEN=asdfasdf python manage.py test
